factoid: The valet brought a woman's fox-lined cloak.
Dólokhov shouted "Fool, I told you the sable one! Hey, Matrëna, the sable!" so that his voice rang far through the rooms.
A handsome, slim, pale-faced gypsy girl with glittering black eyes and curly blue-black hair, wearing a red shawl, ran out with a sable mantle on her arm.
The gypsy girl said "Here, I don’t grudge it—take it!" She was evidently afraid of her master and yet regretful of her cloak.
Dólokhov took the cloak, threw it over Matrëna, and wrapped Matrëna up in it.
Dólokhov said "That’s the way, and then so!" He turned the collar up round Matrëna’s head, leaving only a little of her face uncovered.
Dólokhov asked "And then so, do you see?" He pushed Anatole's head forward to meet the gap left by the collar, through which Matrëna's brilliant smile was seen.
Anatole said "Well, good-by, Matrëna" and kissed Matrëna.
Anatole said "Ah, my revels here are over. Remember me to Stëshka. There, good-by! Good-by, Matrëna, wish me luck!"
Matrëna said "Well, Prince, may God give you great luck!" in her gypsy accent.
Two troykas stood before the porch and two young drivers held the horses.
Balagá took his seat in the front troyka and, holding his elbows high, arranged the reins deliberately.
Anatole and Dólokhov got into the front troyka with Balagá.
Makárin, Khvóstikov, and a valet seated themselves in the other sleigh.
Balagá asked "Well, are you ready?"
Balagá cried "Go!" twisting the reins around his hands, and the troyka tore down Nikítski Boulevard.
Balagá shouted "Tproo! Get out of the way! Hi!... Tproo!..." The shouting of Balagá and the sturdy young fellow seated on the box was all that could be heard.
On Arbát Square the troyka collided with a carriage. Something cracked, shouts were heard, and the troyka flew along Arbát Street.
After turning along Podnovínski Boulevard, Balagá began to rein in and drew up at the crossing of old Konyúsheny Street.
The young fellow on the box jumped down to hold the horses.
Anatole and Dólokhov went along the pavement.
When they reached the gate, Dólokhov whistled.
The whistle was answered, and a maidservant ran out.
The maidservant said "Come into the courtyard or you’ll be seen; she’ll come out directly."
Dólokhov stayed by the gate.
Anatole followed the maid into the courtyard, turned the corner, and ran up into the porch.
Gabriel, Márya Dmítrievna’s gigantic footman, met Anatole.
The footman said "Come to the mistress, please" in his deep bass, intercepting any retreat.
Anatole asked in a breathless whisper, "To what Mistress? Who are you?"
The footman said "Kindly step in, my orders are to bring you in."
Dólokhov shouted "Kurágin! Come back!" and "Betrayed! Back!"
After Anatole entered, Dólokhov remained at the wicket gate and struggled with the yard porter who was trying to lock it.
With a last desperate effort, Dólokhov pushed the porter aside. When Anatole ran back, he seized the porter by the arm, pulled him through the wicket, and ran back with him to the troyka.
Márya Dmítrievna found Sónya weeping in the corridor.
Márya Dmítrievna made Sónya confess everything.
Márya Dmítrievna intercepted the note to Natásha, read it, and went into Natásha’s room with it in her hand.
Márya Dmítrievna said "You shameless good‑for‑nothing!" and "I won’t hear a word."
Pushing back Natásha, who looked at Márya Dmítrievna with astonished but tearless eyes, Márya Dmítrievna locked Natásha in.
Márya Dmítrievna gave orders to the yard porter to admit the persons who would be coming that evening but not to let them out again.
Márya Dmítrievna told the footman to bring them up to her.
Márya Dmítrievna seated herself in the drawing room to await the abductors.
